prompts.text: Are you sure to cross anyway?
You managed to successfully cross the the road during a red light.
Do you want to go back to explore a bit more?
Usually the lines on the ground help you navigate. But now that you are crossing during a red light, are they still as helpful?
The traffic you are trying to avoid is certainly still using their lines.
As you take a step forward, you feel the pressure from the people around you standing still.
They are all somewhat neatly alligned to walk when and where they are supposed to.
A green walking man shows up on all lights for the pedestrians. It is your time to go.
You are crossing the street.
I have one last interesting observation about how the people around you are crossing the street.
You found all actors that help you to cross safely.
Now the only thing in your way are the cars driving by.
As you are getting closer, there is something holding you back.
On the other side is a red light formed like a man standing still and expecting you to do the same.

options.text: Why is it shaped like that?
Am I the only one stopping?

prompts.text: Would you like to wait for the green light to appear officially granting you passage?
You are standing infront of the street you want to cross.
You will probably return to this place a few times.
Use the map to go to other places.
There is nothing new to be found.
Someone is scrossing the street on a red light.
She is gay and does crime.

In the tradition of hiding otherwise lost credit in eastereggs:
Thank you to everyone who endured me talking about traffic lights a lot!
This is the end.
Thanks for playing!

Stats:
The game contains exactly 99 turns and 5248 words.

options.text: Subjects that did not make it into the text.

prompts.text: German Road and Transport Research Association

The Forschungsgesellschaft für Straßen- und Verkehrswesen (FGSV) produces the technical regulations for the entire road and traffic sector in Germany. It is a non-profit technical-scientific association and was founded in 1924. According to its statutes, the main objective of the FGSV is the further development of technical knowledge on the entire road and traffic sector.
One of these standards is the RILSA
The FGSV is a very powerful actor in shaping this place. They are not without critique.

Zur Reformbedürftigkeit der For-
schungsgesellschaft für Straßen-
und Verkehrswesen e. V.

Representatives of organisations with non-transport interests (such as: Social affairs, climate
matic protection, etc.) are practically not represented in the working committees of the FGSV e. V..
While walking somewhere, you reach a place that makes you stop.
Another street is crossing you and you want to get to the other side
For a second you think "there is something more about this place, how interesting".
But maybe it is simply customary to stop here.

options.text: Tell me more about this thought

prompts.text: I will give you a few basic infos about this adventure.
You can decide to read more about them or go on.
Remember, when these subjects become relevant, you will have the chance to jump there again.
So feel encouraged to follow what seems interesting.

options.text: About the scope of this project

prompts.text: This adventure is a final paper to a seminar called Experimenting with Ethnography.
During the seminar, we were encouraged to try out new techniques and challenge known ones in the field as well as in the writing.
You will encounter subjects that I have asked pedestrians about.
All of the questions have been asked while they were waiting for the traffic light that I was oberserving to turn green.
For each question I spoke to 20 - 40 people each, mostly during day time and on different days of the week.
I asked any person waiting without selection.

As fieldwork, writing and development of this website all takes a considerable amount of time, this project is better to be understood as a testrun rather than a full presentation of what a text adventure can be.
However, the code has been developed to be used and expanded in future projects.
It includes a complete editor and a platform to play the game.
During the seminar, I got interested in the interactions happening on traffic crossings.
Finally, I decided to focus on the peoples ability to manouver complex traffic situations seamlessly.
Many related subjects did not make it in this version.
However, with enough time they would fit well into the adventure and benefit the idea of exploration.
The actor network theory proved to be useful in thinking and writing about my fieldwork.
It gives me the ability to discover all the non-human elements in the field and attempt to let them speak for themselves.
The ANT was helpful for my oberservation and writing style but is not explicitly part of this text.
This text is a text adventure, but why?
Personally, I sometimes struggle with reading academic texts.
At the same time, I have a Game Design background. So this was the ideal chance to try out different forms of communication.
I believe the text adventure to be a useful addition to a scientists toolbox.
The idea is to keep some of the complexity of the field experiencable for the reader as they can interact with the text and explore a currated version of the field themselves.
Two islands are in the middle of the street. One is part of the pedestrian crossing, the other is not.
He enters a shop on the other side.
If you were to stay for a bit longer, you would see him take the same path back to where he came from - somewhere behind you.
All of this seems to be rather routinely.
A young man looks to his left, takes a few determined steps towards the island outside of the official path.
He stops for a second, makes sure the second half is secure after letting a car through and reaches the other side.
This jaywalker shows a remarkably elegant urban skillset of maneuvering his environment.

options.text: About that island and the official path

prompts.text: Today jaywalking is a common term.
The action of walking across a street at a place where it is not allowed or without taking care to avoid the traffic.
In the early 20th century it meant something else.
A jay was a country hayseed out of place in the city. By extension, a jaywalker was someone who did not know how to walk in the city.

options.text: What is the origin of that term?

prompts.text: During the early 20th century, cars became more popular and entered the cities.
Up to this point the city streets where social spaces between people, carriages and streetcars.
There was little space for fast driving cars.
During the 1910s and 1920s, competitors fought to retain, or establish, legitimate title to the streets. Language was a weapon in this battle.
Pedestrians forced from the streets by aggressive motorists blamed the problem on spoiled "joy riders," and were in turn dismissed as boorish "jay walkers" by irritated drivers.
I learned how exhausting and complex fieldwork can be, especially with plenty of insecurities whether watching something in the field is scientific or not.
I learned how difficult it is to bring all these observations, ideas, impressions and so on into concise writing. And how rewarding it is to finally find a lead towards structuring it all.
I learned yet again how easy it is to underestimate the time neccessary for a project.
Different symbols are used in different places. Vienna, for example, tried to increase attention and visibility by using couples, instead of a single person. They licensed the design to other cities.
Mainz uses the famous Mainzelmännchen in some places.
The Eastgermany symbol became an official exception after some protest.

options.text: Aren't the rules very strict or why are there exceptions?

prompts.text: Technically, many of the rules, written by the FGSV and enacted by the ministry, are only advisory.
While communal officials are part of the FGSV and thus help make the standards, they don't always have to follow them. Though mostly they do. Standardised production is cheaper as well.
As cars like straight roads, sidewalks are, like the name suggests, always on their sides. So sidewalks are mostly parallel to each other.
The shortest way to connect two parallel lines is with a third line orthogonally to them.
Each of the three crossings connects these particular sidewalks.
And this is how it ought to be!

options.text: Why is this so important for the FGSV?

prompts.text: On the ground are many white lines. They govern the traffic flow in much the same way as the lights or the heavier islands.

options.text: How do people interact with the lines?

prompts.text: About a hundred years ago, it was a tough battle to convince people to only cross streets at certain points.
Those who do not take the shortest route were mocked as jaywalkers, unable to oblige to the modern rules of efficient traffic.
While the fight in the USA was much rougher than in Germany, organisations like the FGSV managed to use the same arguments to produce a similar road design.
Cars drive in the direction of the arrows.
On a green light for the pedestrians one side will always be empty. These are the zones marked in red.
The blue zones are the ones most likely to be used as a shortcut outside of the lines.
However, people do not use the space between the crossings in the same way as shown in the next example.
While pedestrians still take shortcuts on the end of the crossings as marked in blue, they do not use the diagonals marked in red.
In theory, the entire area between the two crossings on the main road is free of cars.
However, unlike the blue corners, this seems to be less intuitive to the pedestrian.
Especially as the actual street is not as tidy as this drawing.
It is difficult to judge at first glance whether or not it is safe to take the shorter diagonal, therefore people do not take it.
Pedestrians intuitively understand the rules when and how they are officially allowed to cross. They understand the rules for cars as well.
When they are reasonably secure about remaining in a safe area, they will cross lines and rules to their benefit.
In that sense, even though they are not always respected, the lines remain a fundamental guideline for pedestrians.
Most lines are drawn at 90° angles. For pedestrians all of them are.
Most people stay within the lines most of the time.
The few times when they do not are very interesting.

options.text: When do they breach the lines and why?

prompts.text: You can click on the button "overview mode". All places you have visited are marked green.
They have a Jump button as well. So you can visit those you missed.
Some subjects that I looked into but ended up not using. They would be worth further research:
The clicking noises that help visually impaired people.

In general, the alternatives for those who cannot see lines on the ground or lights. For example, in comparision with a city like Marburg which uses a few more design options to make traffic more accessible.
On social media are many people voicing their impressions of being a pedestrian. Especially travel influencer and those who moved to another country.
A differentiation between streets and roads. Possibly stroads as well, as suggested by Strong Towns.
Not everyone is waiting for their official time to cross. However, those who do not are rare.
This street is relatively wide and not directly connecting to a time sensitive place like a bus station.
It is much easier to cross further down the road as well as there are less cars and more visibility.

options.text: How do people behave further down the road?

prompts.text: You are sourounded by a few other pedestrians. On this side as well as on the other side.
Most of them are waiting just like you.
For various reasons, further down the route there is less traffic. Moreover, in contrast to the crossing where we are right now, it is easy to spot incoming cars at a distance.
Even vulnerable and slow people like elders with rollators feel safe enough to cross.
A mere 100 m distance makes the difference between virtually no one crossing a red light to frequent and casual crossing.
Just now you notice the other people around you.

options.text: Tell me about the other people.

prompts.text: Some are just standing around, some are chatting with their groups and others are looking at their phones.
They vary in their patience.
Once I saw two people setting up some improv photoshoot right at the centre.
Despite some people being occupied with conversations, their phones or simply looking in other directions, they all notice green lights.
Very few ever missed it and those who did seemed to feel the need to downplay it.
One of them even switched to the other crossing to disguise their failed attempt.
The street is full with pedestrians and bikes going both ways. Yet no one bumps into each other.
All in all, they posses a great amount of spacial awareness and social skills to communicate evasion manouvers without even speaking.
The sleeping gendarm is an actant, a delegation sent out by engeneers to slow down cars.
Much like that, the red light acts in the name of the police and municipal officials.
However, there is an important difference.
While the sleeping gendarm is cast into concrete and thus holding physical power on its own, the light is merely telling you to stop.
You can certainly try.
Richtlinien für Lichtsignalanlagen - Lichtzeichenanlagen für den Straßenverkehr
Essentially, the rulebook on how to do traffic lights, among other things in Germany.
It is written by the FGSV.
As per the RiLSA this is how it has to look.
6.2.7 Signal heads for pedestrians.

Signal heads for pedestrian signals have two or three aspects (with two red lamps). The green signal is at the bot-
tom. The red signal must have a symbol of a pedestrian
standing waiting, and the green signal must have a sym-
bol of a pedestrian walking (see figure 52). The pedestrian
symbols agreed in the German unification treaty can also
be used.
In praxis, there are some exceptions of course.
Hey my name is Tobias Brinck and these are my fieldnotes in the form of a text adventure I made as part of a seminar.
I will give you a quick tutorial on how to navigate this.
Then I will tell you about what this whole thing is.
Click on the option below to start the tutorial.
It is this feeling that in this very familiar place, there is something strange. It might be worth staying for a moment, look around and let that feeling sink in.
It seems so simple and yet it is very difficult to actually do in the field.
Thats what I did and thats what this story is about. I hope I was able to reconnect these dispersed impressions in this text.
In summary
Pedestrians are adapted to urban life and capable of navigating traffic safely. They have more space to stretch the rules than cars.
How these skills have been aquired has not been answered.
Text adventures are a useful yet time-consuming kind of text if one wants to encourage exploration and expierence.

Text adventures have certain properties that I believe are beneficial for scientific communication.


They are interactive and dialogical.
Academic text in contrast to other forms of writing of course has been established and shaped to suite the needs of academia.
My argument is that academic text works for some kinds of writing within the scientific community but not for all.
Text adventures can be developed into academic text adventures to fill some of the gaps.
Text adventures cannot be cited in a conventional way by page numbers.

Instead, it can be cited by turn numbers.
The number of this turn is displayed on the left.
Making text adventures citable within the scientific discours is only a problem of establishing text adventures as legitimate forms of writing and creating a standard to do so.
Text consists of structuring units, such as chapters, paragraphs or sentences.
Dialogues use an additional unit: turns. Between reader and author this is a turn pair.
This is not new for complex explanatory texts as, for example, Platon's "Republic" is written dialogically.
Although useful in communicating more directly with the reader, any structure requires more time.

Dialogical text makes the source of any sentence explicit.
Voice and credit is automatically given to those who would normally be masked by the more prominent voice of the author.
Linking as many turns as possible to each other increases the chance for the reader to come across most of them.
Adding conditions on central points of the narrative, so that the reader is sent to unread places, ensures a minimal coverage of each chapter.
Ideally, both techniques are overlapping enough, so that the reader does not notice them too much.
These techniques require the author to learn about aspects of game design in addition to their classic writing skills.
Not every single detail is neccesary to understand the idea of a text.
Declaring parts as optional can be a painful act for the writer. I put effort into something and most reader will never see it.
One might even call it inefficient. Either a paragraph holds knowledge and should be read or not.
I argue, that people come to a text for different reasons and they are interested in different details.
Not forcing fellow scientists to read everything I had to say, is the kind thing to do.
And with increased choice for the reader, it will be a better text for most, although only few will have read everything.
By giving the reader a way to check what they have not read yet, they regain agency over where they want to continue much like they have with a printed book.
Despite their interactive properties, text adventures remain printable.
The popular book series "Choose your own adventure" allows the reader to make decisions by going to a specific page, depending on their choices.
This principle can be adopted for scientific text adventures as well.
Text adventures are mainly text. While they can be integrated with other forms of media, this is technically possible with all forms of text.
The main difference is that text adventures are interactive.
A reader can, to some extent, decide on a path through the text.
Ultimatly, the reader can decide not to read parts or read them out of order with any kind of text . The difference is that a text adventure encourages this, whereas academic text does not.
With non-linar text comes the possibility to miss parts of the text.
This can be mitigated through:
In addition to the intrinsic properties of the text adventures, I was experimenting with two styles of writing.
1) Allocating each idea to exactly one paragraph. This is mostly a personal preference but seems to fit dialogical writing.

2) Using multiple voices, even for my own expressions. Tobias, narrator, speculating Tobias. Each declares a specific intent. This is supposed to assist the reader in deciphering which part of the author is currently speaking.
To your left and right, on both sides, on the street are traffic lights. They are long grey poles with lights attached to their upper end.
The lights on your side are facing away from you. The others are facing towards you.
You cannot see it but all of them are showing red for you and green for the cars.
Stop
Although this light is not litterally speaking to you, it could be.
I would like to share a story I was told about traffic lights.
Most people seem to be pressing the button while standing next to it and casually reaching out with one arm sideways.
Please touch - is written on the button
Above that is an empty dark part, waiting to show you another message.
While the main red and green lights are in sync, the secondary signals are not.
Most times pressing a button only activates the text on that very button.
Although there are many execptions which I was unable to find the pattern of. After a few hours this mysterie stays unsolved.
As the people on the other side do not know you pressed your button, they will press theirs.
Probably, they are not actively thinking about you, but intuitively pressing unpressed buttons.
After this fieldtrip, I cannot unsee that and now I no longer press buttons if people are waiting on the other side to send them a gesture of trust. Oh well.
Always give the user feedback.
Especially when the user has to wait. Not knowing that the system already took the input and is processing it, people will get impatient rather quickly.
Pressing, clicking, touching a  button a hundred times triggers equally many unneccesary processes cloging up the system.
This is why we have progress bars, loading circles and the like everywhere in the digital world.
All you have to do has been done, you can place your attention somewhere else now.
A glowing red text appears.
Signal incoming
This reminds me of a design principle I learned about during my education as a programmer.
On the other side are some pedestrians approaching the traffic light as well. They look towards you and press their button.

options.text: But I just pressed the button?

prompts.text: On most traffic lights are plenty more actants that need to be explored.
Various signs, graffiti, sticker, loudspeaker and a yellow button.
We will concentrate on the button.
This story was told to me by a lady in their 80s. I will translate and paraphrase.
I remember a time without traffic lights. I remember a time without traffic.
I was a child and the streets suddenly became very busy. There was a policemen in the middle of the street on a pedastel helping the people.
On one christmas day he was out there and around him was a circle made of little presents.
The people liked him because he cared about their safety.
The police eventually delegated this duty to modern traffic lights and people tell different storys about them.
Aspects of the History of Traffic Signals
It remained for a firm of railway signal manufacturers to successfully build the world´s first traffic signal using colored lights in response to an 1866 suggestion ...
Until this time, people were dependent on policemen´s hand signals an, according to newspaper report of the day, there were often very inadequate defense against accidents.'

In Paris, in 1912 an ornate bronze kiosk 15 feet high was erected at the Rue Montmarte and Grand Boulevard. A policewomen sat in a sort of glass showcase near its top and manipulated a revolving four-sided metal box that stuck out at the top of the kiosk.
Between then and now the traffic light underwent a gradual evolution all over the world.
Whistles, lights, signs and many more were used, each in gas-powered, manual or electric versions.
Standards have been adopted, abandoned, compromised and fought over. In Germany the FGSV was a prominent organisation in this process
I asked people about their perception of the traffic lights they were interacting with. Here are some of them in decreasing order of occurance.
Traffic lights are just there.
They are stressing me out.
I think its good, they give safety, especially for the kids.
Most people do not seem recognise traffic light as active interactions, rather they view them as a given part of urban enviornment.
Some traffic lights speak.
Speaking traffic light have been used to make them less eerie to their early users. And it is a concept that is actually tested again.
I asked some people about speaking traffic lights.
Thank you, it's about to get green.
The first "talking" traffic lights in the city of Siegen passed the test run today before the start of school.
I asked pedestrians what they think how a traffic light would speak if it could.
"RUN!" Not friendly, rushing.
"Go." like Siri, like just normally dull.
Green.
Notice me!
"Stop." I would like it if it was friendly.
Roughly two thirds of all answers were distinctivly neutral. Some people showed curious joy with the idea of engaging in traffic light and about as many answered with a demanding/stressing line.
Cars and bikes are driving by you while you are waiting.
While I was concentrating on the pedestrians I took some notes about the other kinds of traffic as well.
This particular junction is very unclear to navigate for bike riders.

Some of the bike lanes are on the sidewalk, others are not.
Behind us is a pedestrian-only zone. So the bike lanes suddenly end after crossing the street.
On the other side the bike lane is ending in roadworks.
These bike lanes go parallel to the pedestrian ones. But as they seemingly lead nowhere, they are rarely respected by either side and both pedestrians and bikes use both lanes.
In general bikes are able to switch between behaiving like a mobile but vulnerable car and a fast but relativly immobile pedestrian.
Being able to plan a path ahead and evade any obstacles or other participants are the two key skills to navigate urban traffic.
On this crossing bikes often follow one path and then quickly change to another as they notice the unexpectedly complicated situation of bike lanes.
They are forced to adapt and do so, which can seem like very strange behaivior from the outside.
From all participants people in cars are the ones most likely to follow rules.
Probably this is because fines and punishments are higher than for pedestrians.

And because cars are less mobile than pedestrians. Essentially they can go forward and backward wheras pedestrians can quicly move in all directions, adjust their speed, spin and all that is neccessary to evade other traffic.

And less mobile than pedestrians. Can only go forward

Cars can play out their supirir speed and weight in other situations like unofficial crossing locations. When pedestrians are indicating that they want to cross, drivers can simply decide to not slow down.
In comparison to pedestrians people in cars seem to be less patient while waiting for their respective green phase.
Cars have to wait in lines and thus are limited in how many of them can cross during a green phase. Pedestrians on the other hand can all cross in parrallel.
You chose fun facts about animals.
You chose fun facts about numbers.
You chose no fun fact, somehow.
Sometimes you are send to different dialogues depending on where you have been so far.
This one for example checks which fun fact you visited.

Thats all you need to know to play.
If you want to use the editor, try it out or get in touch and I will help you out.
You already got the first and most important step: going to another part of the adventure.
Sometimes there are more than one options. In that case, you choose one.
You will be able to go back. So just take the option that seems more interesting to you.

options.text: Give me a fun fact about animals
Give me a fun fact about numbers

prompts.text: Did you know that manta rays get their name from the Spanish word for blanket (manta). They are floating blankets!
Did you know that computers can never produce truely random numbers?
This is why you can buy books with random digits for when you need something to be really truely random.
That was fun.
Notice how there is no option available right now?
You can jump between subjects by clicking on elements on the right side
You can use an element to jump when in changes color while you haver over it. Your current location is highlighted.
Use this feature to reach the next step.

Now that we can procede on a path and jump around,
we should make sure not to get lost.
There are two functions for that in the upper right corner:
1) A log of jumps you took. From there you can always return to where you came from
2) The overview mode. Here you can see everything. You might want to use that in the end to see if you missed something. I will remind you.
At the moment your progress is automatically saved locally in your browser, but nowhere else.
This works like coockies but technically slightly different. So for now you have to stick to one device and one browser and maybe not use the incognito mode.
Two features were developed but not used, that could still be useful for other projects:
Linking to other places from withing text. [Like this]
Zooming in on the current place in the image instead of outlining it.
As I exclusivly worked with vector graphics this zoom can be infinitly deep. This was intended to model ANT like actants where there is another set of actants inside every actant.
This can be beneficial for more complex texts.
This was intended to give quicker access to related subjects.
Much like in Wikipedia, this would allow to jump to a definition and back, without interupting the flow.
However, this adventure is too small to actually take advantage of this feature. So I removed it entirely to reduce complexity for the reader.
This kind of linking requires more robust ways to bring the reader back to where they came from.
